com.github.westonpace.jayvee.image

Class Interpolator.BilinearInterpolator

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.westonpace.jayvee.image.Interpolator.BilinearInterpolator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Interpolator
    Enclosing interface:
    Interpolator

    public static class Interpolator.BilinearInterpolator
extends Object
implements Interpolator

    Calculates a pixel value from the 4 closest neighbors using bilinear interpolation. It interpolates the top neighbors linearly in the X direction and the bottom neighbors linearly in the X direction. It takes the two resulting values and interpolates them linearly in the Y direction. 

     Example:
              |-a-|--b---| 
            - TL---------TR
            c |          |
            - |  X       |
            | |          |
            d |          |
            - BL---------BR
 
 T = TL * a + TR * b
 B = BL * a + BR * b
 X = T * c + B * d

    The result is (ironically) a non-linear function as it is the product of two linear functions. Bilinear interpolation can often lead to a number of visual artifacts (e.g. aliasing, halos around edges, etc.) and is less accurate than bicubic interpolation. It is more accurate than nearest neighbor interpolation.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      double interpolate(double x, double y, int b, Image source)
      Interpolates a value where the coordinates are not integers by taking the neighbors of the desired point and making some guesses about what the true value should be.

        public double interpolate(double x,
                 double y,
                 int b,
                 Image source)
        Description copied from interface: Interpolator
        Interpolates a value where the coordinates are not integers by taking the neighbors of the desired point and making some guesses about what the true value should be.
        Specified by:
        interpolate in interface Interpolator
        Parameters:
        x - The x coordinate of the pixel
        y - The y coordinate of the pixel
        b - The band that we want the value for
        source - The source image, used to obtain neighboring pixels
        Returns:
        An interpolated guess at the true value of the desired pixel
